entry.title: Beyond the Data Silo: The Convergence of SAP Systems and Modern Data Lake Technologies
entry.content:
In today's enterprise landscape, a fascinating transformation is underway. While SAP systems continue to serve as the backbone of business operations, organizations are discovering that traditional approaches to data management no longer meet the demands of our rapidly evolving digital economy. The challenge isn't just about managing data – it's about turning it into actionable intelligence at the speed of business.

The Evolution of SAP Data Architecture

The SAP ecosystem has long been the backbone of enterprise operations, housing critical business data across its various modules. However, today's digital economy demands more than just robust transaction processing – it requires seamless integration of internal and external data sources, real-time analytics, and AI-driven insights.

The current state of enterprise data presents an intriguing paradox. Consider a typical global manufacturing Company X: Multiple SAP instances span continents, each running critical modules like FI/CO, MM, SD, and PP. In Europe, teams work with one set of customizations and configurations, while their Americas counterparts operate with different chart of accounts and business rules. What seems like a simple question about global inventory levels can spiral into a days-long exercise involving multiple teams, countless Excel sheets, and lengthy email threads.

 

Traditional-architecture

These challenges extend beyond just SAP systems. The integration of external data sources – IoT sensors, market data feeds, social media analytics – adds layers of complexity to an already intricate landscape. The time lag between data creation and insight generation has become a critical bottleneck for business agility.

The Promise of Modern Data Lakes

Modern data lake technologies represent a paradigm shift in how enterprises can manage and utilize their data. These platforms bring transformative capabilities through their support for industry-standard formats, enabling seamless data exchange across the enterprise. Their flexible schema management adapts to changing business needs, while enterprise-grade reliability is ensured through ACID transactions. The ability to access and restore historical data states, combined with unified processing for both batch and streaming workloads, creates a robust foundation for next-generation enterprise data management.

 

The Convergence: A New Enterprise Data Architecture

The future lies in architectures that bring together the best of both worlds – SAP's robust business processes and the flexibility of modern data lakes. This next-generation architecture reimagines how enterprise data flows and interacts:

 

Future-architecture

 This convergence enables a new approach to data governance, where metadata management, data quality rules, and lineage tracking are centralized across both SAP and non-SAP data. Organizations can achieve zero-latency access to operational data with instant synchronization across systems, while performing real-time analytics without impacting transaction systems.

Perhaps most importantly, this convergence creates an AI-ready data foundation. By standardizing data formats for AI/ML workloads and enabling the integration of structured and unstructured data, organizations can fully leverage the power of large language models and generative AI across their enterprise data landscape.

Practical Implementation Strategies

Organizations looking to modernize their SAP data architecture should begin with a focus on high-value scenarios that require integrated data, particularly in areas where real-time insights drive business value. Projects that combine SAP and external data often yield the most significant returns and provide valuable learning experiences for teams. The foundation of this modernization requires implementing modern data lake capabilities alongside existing systems, while establishing unified governance frameworks. Creating semantic layers that abstract technical complexity enables broader adoption across the organization. Organizations must also prepare their data structures for AI workloads, implementing robust data quality measures and building pipelines for continuous data refreshes. 

Conclusion: Preparing for Tomorrow

The convergence of SAP systems with modern data lake technologies isn't just a technical evolution – it's a business imperative. Organizations that successfully navigate this transformation will find themselves better positioned to accelerate innovation through integrated data access, improve decision-making with real-time insights, enable AI-driven business processes, and maintain competitive advantage in the digital economy.

The question isn't whether to embrace this transformation, but how to implement it in a way that maximizes business value while minimizing disruption. As technology leaders, our role is to guide our organizations through this evolution, ensuring we build data architectures that are not just modern, but future-ready.

What steps is your organization taking to modernize its enterprise data architecture? The journey toward unified, AI-ready data platforms is just beginning, and the decisions we make today will shape our ability to compete tomorrow.

entry.title: The Metadata behind SAP Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
On February 13th, 2025, we introduced SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to help enterprises unlock value from their data, using it to power analytics, AI, and automation. Fundamental to BDC are Data Products: curated datasets that are accessible, self-describing, discoverable, and understandable. The value and usability of any data partly depends on the availability and quality of metadata, which is also true for the Data Products of BDC. This blog post provides a deep dive into the metadata for SAP Data Products.

In summary, SAP uses open metadata standards to describe Data Products. The API / data model of Data Products is described in Core Schema Notation Interoperability Specification (CSN Interop). The high-level information about Data Products, their taxonomy and relationships are described in Open Resource Discovery with a focus on taxonomy and connecting Data Products with development, integration, and business-oriented concepts.

 

High-Level Metadata

SAP developed a metadata discovery standard for describing and publishing various types of APIs and events: Open Resource Discovery (ORD). ORD is part of the Apeiro Reference Architecture and is contributed as open source to the European IPCEI-CIS initiative as a standard for interoperability. It was a natural step to leverage this existing standard rather than to create another isolated metadata standard that only covers the Data Product and platform aspects. So, we extended ORD to include the Data Product concept and connected it with other existing developer-focused concepts. 

This also helps with avoiding the typical problem of siloed and fragmented metadata graphs. We believe there is huge value in connecting the various metadata concepts that are relevant to developers, architects, data scientists, and business persona. Our strategy is to bring all these aspects together and aggregate the metadata into central repositories.

In our model, the Data Product is a grouping concept that carries the relevant metadata to describe the dataset and its data qualities. A Data Product itself is not directly consumable, but it exposes data through output ports, which can be implemented as APIs or events. In the first iteration of BDC, the primary Data Products expose a single output port as delta-sharing API. In principle, there can be multiple output ports of various API and/or event types. To understand data ingestion, lineage, and dependencies, Data Products can also have input ports which are the equivalent of an ORD Integration Dependency that lists the APIs and events that are used to ingest or process the data. Most of the concepts have relations to Entity Type, which represents business objects / domain objects / ODM entities as semantic taxonomy terms business experts would understand.

Right now, SAP uses the ORD protocol to streamline our own discovery and publishing processes, most notably to the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) System Landscape, SAP Build and to the BDC Cockpit.  This all happens behind the scenes, so customers are not exposed to it and can benefit from a better integrated experience. However, in our partnership with Databricks, we also use the ORD protocol to connect the Databricks Unity Catalog with the Data Products provided by BDC as well as the other way around, retrieving Data Products created in Databricks into BDC. Leveraging ORD as an open metadata standard is a very important part of our partnership. We are looking forward to growing the ecosystem around ORD in our partnerships.

For more information about Data Products in ORD, have a look at the ORD Data Product page.

 

Data Product API / Data Model

Data Products exposed by SAP applications will use the industry-standard Delta Sharing protocol, but customers will also be able to expose Data Products via other types of APIs. In Delta Sharing, the Delta Table metadata format provides the basics for wider ecosystem interoperability. For many of our use cases, we need even richer metadata – more semantics and a model that is closer to our existing metadata models.

Many SAP products already support the SAP-specific Core Data Services (CDS) metamodel, which may also be known to our customers as the metadata format for ABAP (RAP) and SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP). Since we invested in rich metadata in CDS models for many years (sometimes decades), it made sense to leverage it also for Data Products, preserving and transferring the rich metadata and semantics we often already have.

As CDS models can be exported in the CSN format in many variants and flavors, we created a public specification that focuses on an interoperable, machine-consumption-optimized format: Core Schema Notation Interoperability Specification (CSN Interop).

With CSN Interop, we describe the API / data model of the Data Products output port. The most relevant aspects are that we describe entities (tables / objects) and elements (fields, properties). By assigning entities to a service, we define (or imply) the protocol and mapping how they are exposed as an API with a concrete data serialization format.

Since the CSN format is not well known outside of the SAP ecosystem, here are some interesting aspects:

CSN is well suited to describe “conceptual” models, which are more abstract than, e.g., JSON Schema. The same CSN model can be exposed through different API protocols and data serialization formats (via assignment to a Service). It can also be used as a persistency model for the database. The core entity model in CSN is therefore agnostic of protocol and serialization format. The final API / data interface is then decided by the chosen mapping. In the case of the Delta Sharing APIs, we defined a mapping to the Apache Spark type system.

Also, CSN already has extensive annotation vocabularies, which can carry a lot of additional information like business semantics (@Semantics, @ODM), relationships, and metadata that improve the semantic onboarding experience. This means that there is no need to rebuild a rich, semantic metamodel from scratch, because we can carry over the information. 

For more information, have a look at the CSN Interop page and its Primer.

 

Future Direction

We plan to extend the current scope of the metadata standards and further improve the data product metadata with more annotations and better coverage. We want to establish ORD as a de facto industry standard, being an intrinsic piece of our open ecosystem approach similar as we use ORD as the solid foundation of our partnership with Databricks.

If you have questions, feedback or just want to get in touch with us, feel free to reach out!

To integrate this logs in your Project - Create User and Role:

entry.title: CAPM Basics - Part 1
entry.content:
Hello Colleagues,

Below blog will guide you on how to create a basic CAP application and deploy the application to a persistent SQLite DB. 

Sign in to your global account and launch BAS from your instances and subscriptions.

Create a new Dev Space and select a "Full Stack Cloud Application". This will pre-install the necessary extensions/libraries.

Your new Dev Space is now created. Launch it.

 

 

Browse to the "projects" directory of your Dev Space and open the same.

In the Projects directory, create a new CAP project as shown below. Open terminal and use the command "cds init <project_name>". A sample CAP application with the pre-defined folder structure is created.

In the "db" folder, create a file named "data-model.cds" and paste the contents as below. This creates the entity "trainer" in the namespace "training". 

namespace training;

using {cuid} from '@sap/cds/common';

define entity trainer : cuid {
    name        : String;
    location    : String;
    designation : String

}

In the "srv" folder, create a file named "services.cds". This creates a OData V4 service exposes the entity as a view/projection. 

using training as db from '../db/data-model';

@path: 'MyService'
service CatalogService {
    entity trainers  as projection on db.trainer;
}

Use "cds add data" to add data feature to your project. This will be the sample mock data for testing our application in development.

Add some sample data to the csv file.

From the terminal, run "cds watch" and observe the logs. Our mock data is loaded from the csv file and deployed to in-memory database. This is the default configuration in CAP. Run the application by clicking on the highlighted URL.

The default HTML page of your CAP application loads up. Click on the entity "trainers". A "GET" request is fired to fetch the data for the same entity.

Now return to your CAP application, and create a "test.http" file in the root of your project as shown below.

Write a GET request as shown below and execute the same.

Now write a POST request and execute the same. Hit the "GET all records" request again. Observe a new record is created with a guid assigned by CAP. This is because we used a cuid aspect for our entity which assigns a unique primary key to our entity.

Now stop your CAP application (hit CTRL+C in your terminal), start it again (execute cds watch in your terminal) and execute the above "GET all records" once more. What happens? We only get the records from our csv file. The record that we posted in the previous step is lost. This is because we are using a default in-memory database (ephemeral database) as observed from our logs previously.

To "fix" this, we will now shift to a persistent SQLite DB. To make CAP understand that we want to use a persistent DB instead of a in-memory DB, add the following lines in your package.json file.

{ "cds": { "requires": {
   "db": {
      "kind": "sqlite",
      "credentials": { "url": "db.sqlite" } 
   }
}}}

 

Now execute the command "cds deploy --to sqlite" as shown below. A new file db.sqlite is created which is now our local persistent DB.

Execute "cds watch" to start the application again. Observe the logs. The application is now connected to our persistent SQLite DB instead of in-memory database.

Now POST a new record, stop the application, start the application again and execute the "GET all records" request. What do you observe? The record that was posted is persisted even after restarting the application.

So now you have a fully capable CRUD application service with very minimum development. If you have any questions, please feel free to comment below.

entry.title: SAP BTP: Cloud Application Programming Model
entry.content:
SAP Cloud Application Programming (CAP) Model exposes the ability to extend standard Cloud, on-premises and hybrid application functionality with flexible custom business logic scripted using the developer’s choice of programing language (SQL, SQL Script, Python, Node.js and JavaScript) and exposing the functionality to various user interfaces (UIs) e.g. Microsoft Power Bi, SAP Fiori, Dataiku and Google Big Query using various integration frameworks e.g. OData v4,JDBC/ODBC depending on the case study.

The developer takes pride in delivering a scalable extended functionality, embedding robust real-time monitoring capabilities to ensure a health life cycle and protecting the functionality with secure authentication protocols e.g. OAuth 2.0, JWT Bearer, SAML version 2.0 and RFC Specification.

Furthermore, the developer ensures a reliable and robust solutions by implementing continuous integration and continuous delivery CI/CD pipelines that automates testing, building and deployment of code changes this strategy ensures a speedy development and delivery cycle.

Traditionally developers extended business logic directly on-premises on the ABAP application server. With the ever-changing world of technology, digital transformation has become essential for organization to say afloat of competitors and therefore the programming model paradigms and capabilities of extending SAP solutions have evolved drastically and provides a seamless experience into the cloud.

Figure 1:

Architectural Paradigm Shift from Classic ABAP App server to CAP App server

Source: Thomas Jung, SAP HANA Extended Application Services blog, URL: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blogs-by-sap/sap-hana-extended-application-services/ba-p/12963426/page/4

The SAP Cloud Application model comes with a rich set of languages, libraries, and tools for building enterprise-grade services and applications. It guides developers along a 'golden path' of proven best practices  and a great wealth of out-of-the-box solutions  to recurring tasks:

Figure 2:

SAP Cloud Application Model Architecture

Source HTTPS://Cap.cloud.sap , URL: https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/about/

The below diagram categories the skill set of SAP Cloud Developer based on the scope of the development either being ABAP or Non-ABAP. Each with its unique set of tools and methodologies:

Figure 3:

 SAP Cloud Developer skill set

Source: Building side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP, URL: https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/build-side-by-side-extensions-on-sap-btp/identifying-the-need-for-side-by-side-extensibility_f1e838f0-f02a-43b4-8896-cedc25a7d5d0

The Cloud Application Programming model enables a collaboration of agile cross functional teams inclusive of but not limited, depending on the scope of the development:  citizen developers (low-code/no-code), Professional developers (Scripting, OOP), business analysts, data engineers and application specialists to model robust data models:

Figure 4:

Agile cross functional team

Source: Investigating the Impact of Cross-Functional Teams on Business Success

URL: https://www.iienstitu.com/en/blog/cross-functional-teams

SAP Cloud Application Programming (CAP) Model enables a culture where people regardless of their title or background, work together to imagine, develop, deploy, and operate a solution. This strengthens the trust between employees and authentic healthy work relationships.

Thank you all for taking a glimpse into the above Content. Please don’t for get to like, comment and share.

Abbreviations:

APP: Application

CAP: Cloud Application Programing

CDS: Core Data Services

CI/CD: Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery

JWT: JSON Web token

OData: Open Data Protocol

RFC: Remote Function Call

SAML: Security Assertion Markup Language

SQL: Structured Query Language

UIs: User Interfaces

entry.title: Hilal Kurt
entry.content:
More about Hilal Kurt in SAP Community



First Name, Last Name: Hilal Kurt       
Location (City, Country): Istanbul, Turkey
Occupation: Sr. MM Consultant

 


Hilal, tell us about yourself.
Who are you, what do you like to do, what is important to you?

Hi there! As an SAP MM consultant, I have worked on various projects both domestically and internationally, providing process consultancy. I have a strong interest in new SAP products, especially SAP ALM, Joule, and cloud solutions. 

Being an active member of the SAP Community, I am passionate about organizing events and strengthening the SAP ecosystem. Contributing to SAP Inside Track, CodeJam and similar events excites me, as I love sharing knowledge and engaging with the community. 

Outside of work, I have been actively practicing sports and yoga for many years. I believe maintaining both mental and physical balance has a positive impact on professional life. I continue to learn, share, and grow together with the SAP Community!


What is your area of expertise?
What does a usual day at work look like for you?

As an SAP MM consultant, I specialize in sourcing and procurement and inventory management processes. Throughout my career, I have worked on both domestic and international projects, focusing on process optimization and system implementations. My expertise extends to SAP ALM, Joule, and cloud solutions, where I explore innovative ways to enhance business processes. 

A typical day for me involves analyzing business requirements, configuring SAP solutions, and collaborating with teams to ensure smooth operations. I spend time troubleshooting issues, optimizing workflows, and keeping up with the latest SAP innovations. Beyond project work, I actively contribute to the SAP Community, organize events, and engage in knowledge sharing to foster a collaborative learning environment.


What inspired you to become an SAP Champion in SAP Community?

Bringing people together, organizing events, and encouraging others to explore new things as a community has always been a passion of mine. This is not just something I do in my professional life, but also an integral part of my daily life. I strongly believe that those working within the SAP ecosystem must continuously adapt to emerging technologies. The ever-evolving solutions, new business models, and constantly changing processes keep us dynamic and energized.

SAP plays a significant role in our lives, and for me, being able to integrate what I love doing outside of work into my professional life is incredibly motivating. I truly love my job because SAP is such a dynamic industry where we encounter diverse and unique business cases every day. Each new case presents an opportunity to learn and grow, making the journey both exciting and rewarding.

This is why I find the "pay it forward, pay it back" philosophy so valuable. I believe that fostering a culture of knowledge sharing within the SAP Community is essential for collective growth. Becoming an SAP Champion allows me to contribute to this vision by sharing my expertise, inspiring others, and strengthening our ecosystem. It’s not just about learning, it's about empowering others, creating opportunities for collaboration, and growing together as a community. That’s what makes this journey truly meaningful for me.


How do you learn in SAP Community?
What is your daily/weekly routine in SAP Community?

I first discovered SAP Community when I started my career. While working on business processes, I often encountered errors and began searching for solutions. I found that the shared experiences and insights in SAP Community blogs provided valuable information. This process helped me realize that SAP Community is not just a knowledge base but also a collaborative learning environment where professionals share their experiences. 

My learning process in SAP Community involves actively following forums and exploring new content related to my areas of interest. I focus on SAP MM, ALM, Joule, and cloud solutions, staying up to date with the latest developments. Since the SAP ecosystem is constantly evolving, exchanging ideas with other professionals and sharing best practices is a great way for me to learn. 

As part of my daily routine, I read SAP Community blogs and forums to stay informed about current topics. On a weekly basis, I make sure to read SAP blogs and documentation to keep up with the latest updates.


What is your suggestion to get the most out of SAP Community?

To get the most out of SAP Community, being an active participant is essential. Instead of just reading content, asking questions, engaging in discussions, and sharing your experiences helps you build a stronger connection within the community. 

Additionally, following the right resources makes a significant difference. Regularly exploring SAP blogs, documentation, and forums ensures that you stay up to date with the latest information and continuously improve your knowledge. 

Another key aspect is attending events and building a professional network within the community. Participating in events like SAP Inside Track allows you to gain new insights and connect with other professionals in the industry. I also contribute by organizing community events and sharing content to help grow the SAP ecosystem. 

Lastly, SAP Community thrives on a culture of knowledge sharing. By embracing the "pay it forward" mindset, sharing what you learn and supporting others in their growth, you contribute to making the community even stronger. The more we share, the more we learn!

entry.title: Grow with SAP for Retail: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition retail, fashion, and vertical business
entry.content:
The evolution of SAP's retail systems

Having dedicated 30 years to SAP and the retail industry, I have had the privilege of witnessing the remarkable evolution of SAP's retail systems. From the first version specifically designed for retail in a ECC system to the continuous improvements over the years, culminating in the sophisticated cloud private edition for retailers, the journey has been extraordinary. And with this cloud private edition, we are still not at the end of this evolution! 

Begin of 2025, SAP proudly introduced the Retail Industry version of our multi-tenant SaaS ERP solution (general availability). This advanced system goes beyond the fundamentals of finance, procurement, and warehouse management to include specialized features such as store management, pricing, promotions, replenishment, allocations, and more. These processes are tailored to the retail sector, drawing on SAP's 50 years of experience collaborating with the world's leading retailers. 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, retail, fashion, and vertical business empowers small and medium-sized enterprises to drive business growth and foster innovation. By standardizing retail-specific processes, this modern, agile, and scalable cloud ERP solution ensures the fastest time to value and the lowest total cost of ownership.

In simple terms, it’s a platform that allows retailers to focus on what they do best: delighting their customers. In an age where customer experience defines success, maintaining this focus is essential.

Are you ready to transform your retail business across the value chain?

Retailers are confronted with three significant challenges: consumers seeking personalized and instant experiences, competitors utilizing technology to drive innovation, and supply chains strained by global uncertainties. Within this crucible of challenges, I believe that Grow with SAP for Retail emerges as an essential lifeline for the contemporary retailer.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, retail, fashion, and vertical business is, at its heart, a holistic cloud ERP solution tailored to the demands of retail businesses. Its goal is to empower retailers to thrive in times of disruption. This solution facilitates the streamlining of business processes, effective data utilization, and flexible scaling.

How could it look like in practice? Let's explore some key aspects of this solution together

To provide a clearer picture, we will step into the shoes of different employees in a retail company and explore their unique challenges, needs, and how they gain advantages from SAP's Public Cloud. Moreover, I will share some example screenshots as a teaser to further illustrate this (the content was built by SAP and demonstrated on NRF 2025).

Melanie, the Procurement Specialist

Melanie, a Procurement Specialist, plays a key role in ensuring the profitability and customer satisfaction of her store by selecting the right products, negotiating prices, and keeping purchases within budget. She relies on sales data to identify products that are in demand.

However, her role comes with several challenges such as errors from manual data entry which lead to inaccuracies, disorganized vendor information increasing costs, limited visibility affecting inventory management, and difficulty in monitoring in-store customer demand for more accurate and timely decisions on stock replenishment and procurement.

To effectively manage these challenges, Melanie needs tools and strategies that allow her to monitor stock levels, assess product performance, handle delivery performance, manage supplier contracts, and analyze sales data for forecasting demand. Implementing solutions like setting automatic reorder points, optimizing purchase orders, and strategies to prevent stock-outs can maximize sales and enhance customer satisfaction.

Utilizing SAP Cloud Public Edition tailored for retail can significantly support Melanie in her role. SAP can help optimize inventory levels, reduce carrying costs through accurate sales forecasting, streamline invoice processing for better supplier compliance, and provide built-in tools for communication and approvals. This streamlines the entire purchasing process, making it more efficient and effective in meeting both the store's and customers' needs.

(The procurement overview dashboard of Procurement Specialist Melanie provides pre-built reports, easy access to precise data)

(The machine learning model for predicting delivery dates utilizes the company's data, incorporating factors such as transportation method, lead time, vendor history, and weather conditions)Phil, the Store Manager

Phil, as the Store Manager, holds the responsibility for the store's smooth operation. He is dedicated to achieving sales targets, maintaining customer satisfaction, and effectively managing his team. His role encompasses strategic planning, team leadership, and operational know-how to propel the store towards success.

However, Phil faces a set of challenges that include balancing inventory to align with customer demands while also minimizing carrying costs, contending with slow restocking processes which can result in empty shelves and lost sales, and dealing with operational inefficiencies that create bottlenecks, impair productivity, and cause delays. 

To address these challenges, Phil's strategy requires developing and implementing methods to meet sales goals and enhance profitability, managing inventory levels to prevent stock-outs and ensure product availability, getting a clear perspective on short-term and long-term promotional activities, and using customer data to personalize recommendations and promotions.

Utilizing the SAP Cloud Public Edition tailored for retail, Phil can gain a suite of benefits to streamline operations and boost efficiency. This includes integrated data facilitating quicker decision-making processes across sales, inventory, and customer operations; enhanced real-time collaboration with local suppliers, which helps in improving lead times and reducing restocking delays; and omnichannel integration that guarantees a consistent customer experience and synchronized inventory management across all platforms. This comprehensive approach not only aids in tackling existing challenges but also positions the store for lasting success.

(Phil opens his store overview page which gives him a snapshot of his daily store operations briefly)
(Demand Forecast Run shows the expected demand for the coming weeks including seasonality)Sarah, the Store Associate
 
Sarah is a dedicated Store Associate with a flair for customer service and teamwork. She helps customers find the right products and ensures smooth transactions through the point-of-sale system. Her duties extend beyond the counter, as she restocks shelves, crafts appealing displays, and double-checks that price tags reflect current offers. The harmony and satisfaction in her workplace motivate her to contribute actively to the store's success, aiming to provide every customer with a pleasant shopping journey.

Despite her enthusiasm, Sarah faces several hurdles in her day-to-day operations. Inventory management can be sluggish and imprecise, leading to situations where products are either unavailable or unnecessarily abundant. This misalignment can make product location cumbersome and detract from customer satisfaction. Additionally, inefficient checkout processes can cause delays, leaving customers feeling frustrated. Her current tools also limit her ability to access insightful data, making it harder to make informed decisions.

With SAP Cloud Public Edition tailored for retail, Sarah's workflow can be optimized, leading to greater productivity. Improved in-store pickup processes minimize revenue loss, ensuring customers receive their orders promptly. Real-time visibility into stock levels empowers her to update customers accurately, fostering trust and satisfaction. Optimized inventory management reduces unnecessary carrying costs, while smart restocking based on actual sales keeps shelves perfectly stocked.

By integrating smart technology, Sarah can overcome her hurdles and elevate both her efficiency and customer satisfaction. entry.title: Clean Core as Foundation for Your Cloud Journey
entry.content:
At the DSAG Technology Days 2025 in Wiesbaden, I had the privilege of presenting alongside @michael_sokollek and @Tobi_F (Tobias Fischer) on “Clean Core as Foundation for Your Cloud Journey.” The enthusiastic engagement from the DSAG [1] community—representing over 4,000 companies across the DACH region—affirmed the relevance and timeliness of our enterprise architecture approach to cloud transformation. The presentation followed why, what, and how sections.

 

WHY Clean Core is the Foundation for Cloud Success

Our presentation emphasized that a clean core is not merely a technical objective but a strategic imperative for sustainable innovation:

  • Continuous innovation enablement: Clean core systematically removes barriers to new software capabilities, allowing organizations to adopt emerging technologies and features
  • Process agility through standardization: Companies operating with standardized systems consistently demonstrate superior process agility, underpinned by higher data quality and streamlined operations
  • Reduced complexity and costs: The clean core approach significantly reduces the complexity and costs associated with upgrades, maintenance, and overall system management
  • Strategic S/4HANA transformation foundation: As an ongoing strategic activity rather than a one-time effort, clean core provides the essential groundwork for successful S/4HANA transformation

The audience response was particularly strong when we showcased the correlation between clean core principles and measurable business outcomes. As one CIO from a mid-sized manufacturing company commented: “We’ve been approaching modernization backward—focusing on features first rather than foundation.”

 

WHAT Our EA-RISE Framework Delivers

We explained how our enterprise architecture approach within RISE with SAP delivers comprehensive support throughout the transformation journey:

  • Structured implementation guidance: RISE-EA provides clear pathways through established methods and pre-configured SAP solutions, eliminating guesswork and reducing implementation risk
  • Complexity transformation: The framework transforms architectural complexity into clear business insights, enabling effective decision-making at both strategic and operational levels
  • Accelerated cloud adoption: By providing specialized reference architectures, we create accelerated pathways for cloud adoption tailored to industry-specific needs
  • Strategic alignment: RISE-EA ensures continuous alignment between business objectives and IT implementation across the entire journey, preventing drift between strategic intent and execution

The detailed exploration of greenfield versus brownfield strategies resonated strongly with attendees facing these decisions, particularly our differentiation between “keep clean” strategies for new implementations and “make clean” approaches for system conversions.

 

HOW SAP’s Toolchain Supports Implementation

The demonstration section of our presentation showcased the practical implementation of clean core principles through:

  • Integrated planning ecosystem: SAP’s toolchain enables seamless planning from Enterprise Architecture Management (EAM) to Business Process Management (BPM), providing end-to-end visibility
  • Collaborative modeling: Process analysis fosters stakeholder alignment through structured modeling and governance frameworks that bring business and IT perspectives together
  • Implementation standardization: Reference architectures establish consistent solution deployment standards, reducing variability and accelerating implementation
  • Continuous optimization: The framework enables sustainable optimization across all five clean core dimensions (Extensibility, Data, Integrations, Processes, Operations) through structured feedback loops

Our live demonstration of the Clean Core Scoring Framework, including performance KPIs and governance maturity assessments, provided attendees with tangible tools to measure their progress toward clean core objectives.

 

Impact and Response

The session attracted a diverse audience ranging from mid-sized business process owners to CIOs. The engagement level—particularly during our exploration of process deviation management practices—highlighted the DSAG community’s commitment to moving beyond technical approaches to embrace architectural thinking.

Several attendees approached us afterward to discuss how they could apply our five clean core principles within their specific transformation journeys. The most frequent questions concerned practical governance approaches for maintaining clean core principles in organizations with multiple business units and diverse process owners.

For colleagues who missed the session, the presentation materials are available below. I welcome further conversations about how we can apply these principles with your customers to accelerate their cloud journeys while establishing sustainable architectural foundations.

entry.title: The Heart of Transformation: People, Process, and Persistence
entry.content:
(Blog 1 of the “Transformation in Field Service” series)

Introduction

When we hear the word transformation, our minds often jump to technology—shiny new tools, artificial intelligence, mobile apps, cloud platforms. But in my experience working in Field Service—and as a parent, gardener, and lifelong learner—I’ve found that successful transformation isn’t just digital.

It’s deeply human.

The Family Trip That Almost Didn’t Happen

A few weekends ago, we planned a “short” hike as a family. With a three-year-old and a four-year-old in tow, I expected some negotiation. One wanted to stay and build a fort in the living room. The other had already left the house wielding a stick like an explorer on a mission. My partner and I were somewhere in the middle—juggling snacks, sunhats, and our sanity.

What made the hike possible wasn’t the gear or the route. It was alignment, motivation, and compromise. We adjusted expectations. Built excitement. Let the kids help plan the snack break. And eventually, we all made it to the top—tired, proud, and a little muddy.

Honestly? That’s what transformation looks like.

What It Means for Field Service

The same lessons apply when transforming service operations. You might be rolling out new scheduling software or launching mobile tools for technicians. On paper, the plan looks perfect. But in reality, adoption lags. Resistance creeps in.

Why? Because technology alone doesn’t change behavior.

Successful transformation requires:

  • People who feel involved, heard, and capable

  • Processes that are redesigned—not just digitized

  • Persistence to navigate detours, doubts, and delays

📘Want a model? Try Kotter’s 8-Step Change Model

Dr. John Kotter’s framework is widely used in business transformation. It emphasizes:

  1. Creating urgency

  2. Building a guiding coalition

  3. Forming a strategic vision

  4. Enabling action by removing barriers

  5. Celebrating short-term wins

  6. And anchoring the changes in culture

Explore the full model →

Technology Is the Enabler, Not the Driver

Tech is powerful. But it’s like giving my kids high-end hiking gear. If they don’t know where they’re going—or why—the gear ends up in the mud.

In Field Service, this means:

  • Involving technicians when introducing mobile apps

  • Listening to dispatchers when reimagining cloud-based workflows

  • Aligning leadership KPIs to real-world service outcomes—not just feature checklists

🧠 Need a practical tool? Consider ADKAR

I have seen companies successfully applying the ADKAR model from Prosci that helps manage individual transitions across 5 stages:

  • Awareness of the need for change

  • Desire to participate in the change

  • Knowledge of how to change

  • Ability to implement change

  • Reinforcement to sustain change

More on ADKAR from Prosci →

What’s Next in This Series

This is the first post in a five-part series exploring key transformations in Field Service:

  • This Part 1: The Heart of Transformation: People, Process, and Persistence

  • Part 2: Embracing AI in Field Service: From Garden Tools to Smart Assistance

  • Part 3: From Paper to Pocket: How Mobile Transformed the Technician’s Day

  • Part 4: Migrating from on-premise solutions to cloud dispatching

  • Part 5: Transitioning to S/4HANA

And throughout: putting people, process, and persistence at the center.

🌱Book tip: Switch: How to Change Things When Change Is Hard

A highly readable book by Chip & Dan Heath, which uses the metaphor of the rider, the elephant, and the path. In Field Service, you often need to steer minds (rider), motivate hearts (elephant), and shape the environment (path).

entry.title: Custom Widgets in SAP Analytics Cloud - Increased flexibility for Reporting and Planning
entry.content:
What is a SAC Custom Widget? 

The SAP Analytics Cloud offers companies a powerful platform for business intelligence, planning and predictive analyses. SAC provides a large number of standard widgets - so-called basic widgets - with which reports and dashboards can be designed quickly and effectively. Even though these basic widgets cover many common requirements and support a total of 21 different chart types, users sometimes come up against limitations when it comes to more specific visualization requirements. 

This is exactly where custom widgets come into play: these are individually developed visualization elements that go beyond what SAP offers as standard. A SAC custom widget is essentially a web component that consists of a JSON file for the description, JavaScript code for the behavior and optional additional resources such as CSS or images. This allows new chart types as well as customized user interface elements, interactions or even completely new functionalities to be implemented. 

 

GRAPHIC 1: EXAMPLE OF A CUSTOM WIDGET

 

 

Custom widgets offer developers full control: they can design their own diagrams and visualizations from scratch that are perfectly tailored to the specific requirements of a company - be it an interactive network diagram, a dynamic map view or a customized user interface. Thanks to the integration in SAC Stories and the support of the script API, custom widgets fit seamlessly into the existing environment and can be conveniently integrated into Stories via drag & drop. 

Custom widgets therefore allow the SAP Analytics Cloud to be expanded considerably - both in terms of visual design and functional depth. They are the ideal tool if the standard options are not sufficient and the focus is on individual visualization requirements. 

Application scenarios for custom widgets in the SAP Analytics Cloud 

Custom widgets open up a wide range of possible applications in the SAP Analytics Cloud, especially when standard widgets are not sufficient to meet specific requirements. A key area of application is the development of tailor-made visualizations that go beyond the 21 chart types available in the standard system. 

 

GRAPHIC 2: CUSTOM WIDGETS ARE AS INDIVIDUAL AS YOUR COMPANY'S REQUIREMENTS

 

For example, companies can create their own KPI tiles that contain numerical values as well as contextual information such as deviations or trend indicators. In addition, custom widgets enable the integration of interactive user interface elements such as calendars, date pickers or barcode generators that are required in specific business processes. The integration of SAPUI5 controls is also possible, allowing existing components to be reused and complex applications to be implemented efficiently. 

Another scenario is the extension of the SAC functionality by integrating external data sources or APIs. For example, custom widgets can visualize data from third-party systems in real time or enable specific interactions that cannot be realized with standard widgets. This offers companies the flexibility to tailor their dashboards and analyses precisely to their individual needs.  

Overall, custom widgets in the SAP Analytics Cloud offer a powerful way to extend standard functionalities and efficiently implement individual requirements. They are particularly advantageous when specific visualizations, user interactions or data integrations are required that go beyond the standard. 

Custom widgets in detail - how they work in the SAP Analytics Cloud 

Custom widgets can be seamlessly integrated into SAP Analytics Cloud Stories and behave like any other standard widget. After successful deployment, they are automatically listed in the widget menu so that they can be dragged and dropped onto the canvas and placed there. Once inserted, custom widgets can be flexibly moved, resized and visually designed - just like native components in SAC. 

 

GRAPHIC 3: ADD CUSTOM WIDGETS

 

Developers and users benefit from a wide range of functions. Basic properties such as color, font or frame can be adjusted via the styling panel. What is particularly interesting is that in the “Additional properties” section, you can add your own options that have been specially defined for the respective custom widget. Additional settings and functions can be stored in the builder panel, for example for data binding or initializing interactions. 

Custom widgets also support direct data binding, which means that they can be connected to data sources - a key requirement for interactive and data-driven visualizations. In the widget structure within a SAC story, custom widgets appear like any other component and can therefore be easily organized and targeted. 

Another powerful feature is the scripting capability: custom widgets can be addressed via the familiar SAC script API. In addition to the methods available as standard, you can also define and implement your own events - such as an onClick that triggers certain actions when the widget is clicked. This flexibility makes Custom Widgets a versatile tool that can be deeply integrated into SAC, both visually and functionally. 

Technical requirements and authorizations 

The development and use of custom widgets in the SAP Analytics Cloud requires specific technical prerequisites and authorizations. By default, SAP roles are restricted to read access. To create or update custom widgets, users must be assigned additional authorizations. These authorizations can either be set globally for all custom widgets or individually per widget. In particular, widget designers require the rights to create and update widgets. 

Several files are required to create a custom widget, including a JSON file to define the metadata and a JavaScript file for the functionality. These files are packed into a ZIP file together with optional resources such as CSS files or images. This ZIP file is then uploaded directly to the SAC, eliminating the need for external hosting. 

The development environment for custom widgets includes tools such as Visual Studio Code, a free editor from Microsoft that is particularly suitable for editing HTML and JavaScript. To create complex charts, developers can integrate free chart libraries such as ECharts, D3.js or Chart.js to realize advanced visualization options. 

 

GRAPHIC 4: DEVELOPMENT ENVIRONMENT

 

However, there are currently certain limitations when using custom widgets. For example, only Chromium-based browsers such as Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge are fully supported. In addition, the number of custom widgets that can be loaded into a single SAC tenant is limited to 50. 

Some features of the SAC are not supported by custom widgets. These include themes and CSS adjustments, pause refresh, commenting, scheduling, translations, data change insights and the “Search to Insight” function. Restrictions may also occur when exporting custom widgets to PDF, especially if certain chart libraries such as D3.js are used or if CSS settings are defined in the widget. 

There are numerous examples for references in the SAP Community and in SAP Help: 

  • SAP Analytics Cloud Custom Widget Developer Guide 
  • SAP Custom Widget examples on GitHub 
  • SAP Technology Blog: Custom Widgets & Widget Add-Ons 
  • Echarts library examples 
  • SAP Analytics Cloud Widget Add-On Developer Guide 
     

Your path to SAP Analytics Cloud Custom Widgets 

The introduction of custom widgets in the SAP Analytics Cloud offers companies an outstanding opportunity to expand their analytics solutions individually and to tailor them visually and functionally to specific requirements. To maximize the benefits, we recommend a structured and proven approach. 

  1. requirements analysis: In initial workshops, we work with you to analyze the technical, functional and content requirements for the planned custom widget. In this way, we ensure that all stakeholder needs are understood and taken into account - from IT to the specialist department. 
  2. proof of concept: We then develop an initial minimum viable product (MVP) to demonstrate the technical feasibility. This PoC serves as the basis for further decisions and for internal coordination with relevant teams. 
  3. implementation: Based on the PoC, we add the required functionalities to the widget, test it in your SAC environment and hand over the finished custom widget as part of a clean documentation and handover. 
  4.  

GRAPHIC 5: EVALUATION

 

Custom widgets are a modular building block for making a variety of advanced functions usable in SAC - from individual visualizations to complex interactions. They promote acceptance among end users and enable customized solutions for company-specific challenges. At the same time, you should consider the increased development effort compared to standard widgets and the possible training requirements for your team - because individual developments also require internal know-how in the long term.

The below snippet is a Groovy script used for dynamic routing . It reads the root tag from the XML payload and sets the route name in the property routeTo based on the tag value. 

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.util.XmlSlurper

Message processData(Message message) {
    def body = message.getBody(String) // Get XML as a string
    def xml = new XmlSlurper().parseText(body) // Parse XML

    def targetRoute = ""

    // Check the root element or a specific tag (adjust as needed)

        targetRoute = "publisher_solace_inbound_books_layer_2"
    }

    message.setProperty("routeTo", targetRoute) // Store the route in a property
    return message
}

entry.title: Connect to Public Cloud API in Node.js via Authorisation Code
entry.content:
Connecting to a Public Cloud API (from Business Accelerator Hub) via Node.js CAP application can be challenging. I hope this blog helps others attempting the same task.

 Prerequisites

• SAP BTP subaccount (Cloud Foundry)
• Service key for the target Public Cloud API
• XSUAA instance bound to your CAP app
• SAP BTP Destination service instance
• Bruno installed for manual testing

 

1. Confirm the API's Auth Options

First, check which authentication methods are available for the API you plan to consume.

In my example I connect to the Specification Management API, but the steps apply to any Public Cloud API.

If the OAuth 2.0 Access Code Flow is listed under “Authentication Methods”, the API supports the authorization-code flow. That flow confirms a user context and usually grants wider authorisations, such as update and POST requests.

(OAuth 2.0 Application Flow corresponds to the client-credentials flow.)

2. Connect manually with Bruno (Good blog on Bruno)

Because our API supports the auth-code flow, we first prove we can log in by calling it via Bruno.

Create a new collection and paste the base URI of your Public Cloud API instance (you’ll find it in the service key in your service instance of the saas application your connecting to).

When you send a test GET request you will probably receive an authorisation error. Configure OAuth 2.0 on the Auth tab

Select Grant type Authorisation Code

Then fill in the below fields using your service key from your service instance

  • Callback URL: <your Public Cloud API hostname>
  • Auth URL:** https://<subdomain>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/authorize
  • Access-Token URL: https://<subdomain>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
  • Client ID / Secret: from the uaa section of the service key

Request the token, pick your identity provider, and Bruno will return an access token. Inspect the scopes there to see what you can do.

3. Connect to the API from Node.js

After the manual check we can now automate the flow in a Node.js service.

3.1 Destination setup

Create a destination that points to the same API endpoint and bind it to your app.

The required scopes and the audience (aud) value are visible inside the Bruno access token.

the Audience should start with the client id of your CAP application on BTP

Once the destination is saved, ensure your application is bound to the Destination service.

3.2 xs-security.json

Add every scope your service needs so the approuter, it will forward it in the user’s JWT: in my example i needed this scope.

{
  "name": "$XSAPPNAME.Spc_Write",
  "description": "Allow modification of specifications."
}

Also reference the scope in authorities (and role templates, if used) and assign the resulting role collection to your user.

3.3 Connect in code

Now time to connect to the API in the code itself.

First, obtain the user’s JWT. This helper below tries every possible source and falls back to LOCAL_USER_JWT in local development:

/** Try every source for a JWT and fall back to LOCAL_USER_JWT. */
function getJwt(capReq) {
  // CAP ≥ 7.3 keeps the raw token here
  if (capReq.user?.jwt) return capReq.user.jwt;

  // Plain HTTP / WebSocket headers
  const hdrs = capReq.http?.req?.headers || {};
  const token =
        hdrs['x-approuter-authorization'] ||   // CF WebSocket
        hdrs.authorization;                    // CF HTTP

  if (token) return token.replace(/^Bearer\s+/, '');
  // Last resort for local dev
  return process.env.LOCAL_USER_JWT;
}

3.3.1 Testing locally

When testing locally we don't have access to the user JWT so we can add it manually to the environment file so we can still test locally, below is the process to get the JWT for user testing (each token lasts about 7 to 8 hours)

Step 1 – Get an auth code
https://<instance>.eu10.authentication.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/authorize
?response_type=code
&client_id=<XSUAA client id of your deployed app>
&redirect_uri=http://localhost
&state=xyz

Paste your version into your browsers address bar, after login you will land on http://localhost/?code=<AUTH_CODE>&state=xyz. Copy the value of AUTH_CODE.

Step 2 – Exchange the code for a JWT

I made the Curl Request inside BAS itself. it will return a number of tokens, we only need the first and biggest one.

curl -v -X POST \
-u '<same client id>' \
--data-urlencode grant_type=authorization_code \
--data-urlencode code=<AUTH_CODE> \
--data-urlencode redirect_uri=http://localhost \
https://<instance>.eu10.authentication.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token

Save the token from the response into .env:

LOCAL_USER_JWT=<paste JWT here>

3.3.2 Call the destination with the JWT

const jwt = getJwt(req);
if (!jwt) req.reject(401, 'No user token found.');

const dest = await getDestination({
  destinationName: '<DestinationName>',
  jwt
});
await executeHttpRequest(dest, {
  method: 'POST',
  url: `/odata/v4/api/specification/v1/${EntityName}`,
  data: v
});

If you reach the destination but receive 401 Unauthorized, your JWT is missing the correct scope—ask the product team which one you need.

Other common pitfall is using the different XSUAA instances to get your JWT for the local run. use your applications XSUAA client since this is the same one your application will check the token against

And that’s it! You should now be able to read from and write to the Public Cloud API. For read-only workloads the client-credentials flow is usually simpler.

If I missed anything or you’d like more details, please comment below—happy to help.

 

## Frequently Asked Questions

### What’s the difference between authorization-code and client-credentials flows?
The authorization-code flow runs in a user context, so it can carry user-level scopes (read, write, update). The client-credentials flow operates with a technical user—perfect for background jobs or read-only integrations.

### Why do I get “401 Unauthorized” after deployment?
Your user’s JWT is probably missing the required scope (e.g., `Spc_Write`). Make sure the scope is listed in xs-security.json, mapped to a role template, and assigned via a role collection in the BTP cockpit.

### Which audience value belongs in my destination?
Use the client ID of your CAP application’s XSUAA instance; it usually starts with `sb-<appName>!t<number>`.
