entry.title: Understanding the Distinct Scope of SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
As organisations evaluate deployment options for their ERP systems, SAP Cloud ERP Private are often compared without taking the full scope of services into account. Yet, its unique architecture and comprehensive service model make direct comparisons challenging - and frequently misleading.

Traditional comparisons tend to overlook many of the embedded services that come standard with SAP Cloud ERP Private and ignore many of the available options, inadvertently giving other deployment models an apparent advantage. This not only skews perception but also obscures the full value SAP delivers out of the box.

To bring clarity to this discussion, we highlight the key services included in SAP Cloud ERP Private. Our goal is to empower customers with a clear understanding of what they receive, helping them make informed decisions based on a complete picture.

Modernise your ERP system while retaining your investment

SAP aims to transition all customers using SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA by 2027. Before the introduction of RISE with SAP in 2021, SAP did not fully meet the needs of customers seeking cloud-based ERP solutions. The primary option available was S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, which required a new implementation. This was not a viable option for many existing SAP ERP customers who wanted to retain their investment in their current systems, leverage existing data, and carry forward customizations and modifications.

To address this gap, SAP introduced SAP Cloud ERP Private solutions with the launch of RISE with SAP. These single-tenant solutions offer each customer their own dedicated instance of SAP software, hosted on separate infrastructure within a data center operated by one of the major hyperscalers or SAP itself. Existing SAP ERP customers can choose to either lift-and-shift their SAP ERP systems or transition to SAP Cloud ERP Private using a system conversion, selective data transition, or a new implementation approach.

With SAP Cloud ERP Private, SAP is taking away the complexity of designing, building and operating SAP software for our customers. We're doing this by providing a user or metric-based subscription model that includes the software and tooling license, infrastructure and technical managed services - everything that you need to run an SAP solution.

SAP Design, Build and Operate the entire SAP technical solution stack

SAP Enterprise Cloud Services (ECS), the business unit in SAP who is responsible for design, build and operate of Cloud ERP Private, delivers a robust framework for operating SAP Cloud ERP Private solutions, combining infrastructure, software licensing, and technical managed services into a unified subscription model. This approach simplifies the complexity of running SAP systems in a private cloud while ensuring enterprise-grade performance, security, and compliance.

SAP ECS invests heavily in capabilities that ensure robust system design, rapid setup and delivery, and a high degree of automation for operational tasks. This section outlines the key activities performed by SAP ECS, categorized into three phases - Design, Build, and Operate.

The diagram below highlights the key cost elements covered in SAP Cloud ERP Private for the design, build and operation of SAP, while customers retain the responsibility and control of the application layer throughout the three phases. This is valid for every implementation and every time technical changes are made to the SAP system landscape, reducing technical tasks for customers so they can focus more on the business:

The SAP Cloud ERP Private service cover key cost elements for the setup and operation of SAP

The process of designing, building and operating SAP requires broad areas of technical expert competence and requires answers to many detailed technical questions necessary to make strong architecture design decisions. In SAP Cloud ERP Private, this complexity is moved away from being a customer responsibility to the responsibility of SAP and SAP will have the answers during the design, build and operate phases.

1. Design Phase

The primary goal of the Design phase activities is to define standard and configurable cloud-based architectures for SAP ERP systems that enable rapid deployment, customer choice to cater to their unique requirements and minimum manual overhead while meeting SAP’s stringent availability, Recovery Time Objective (RTO), and Recovery Point Objective (RPO), Service Level Agreements (SLAs), security and compliance standards. SAP ECS periodically reviews and refines these architectures and operational processes considering improvements in Hyperscaler infrastructure capabilities, 3rd party tools and services and SAP ECS’s own operational experience.

There are several complex topics that need to be addressed during this phase:

  • Which hyperscaler building blocks to use?
  • Which virtual machine instances are the right fit and certified by SAP?
  • What is the security design?
  • How can business continuity be achieved?
  • How should the systems be monitored?
  • How can resources be effectively scaled?
  • What is the architecture design?

Key activities performed by SAP ECS as part of the Design phase:

  • Reference Architectures: SAP collaborates with hyperscalers to define scalable, secure cloud architectures using SAP best practices.
  • Security & Compliance: Network isolation, encryption, intrusion detection, and adherence to ISO/NIST standards.
  • Monitoring & Incident Response System: Proactive incident response systems and tailored architecture advisory services ensure resilience and performance.
  • Cloud Architecture & Advisory: SAP collaborates with customers to define optimal technical architecture, considering each customer’s system sizing, cloud security, networking and technical integration, and business continuity requirements. SAP and customers jointly engage in a Technical Assessment process to ensure the non-functional requirements are met in SAP Cloud ERP Private.

For every SAP ERP customer moving to SAP Cloud ERP Private solutions, an SAP advisory team which is part of ECS (SAP Cloud Architecture & Advisory (CAA) which provides the above Cloud Architecture & Advisory services) or a similar partner advisory team, analyzes customer requirements and determines the best suitable configuration for the customer. By leveraging pre-defined standard and configurable cloud-based architectures defined by SAP, the time taken to define the architectures for each customer is significantly reduced and the decision process is simplified.

2. Build Phase

The primary goal of the Build phase activities is to define how to install, configure and validate the systems
that have been designed. There are several complex topics that need to be addressed during this phase:

  • Which tools should be used?
  • How to ensure systems are built to provide optimal performance?
  • How to migrate existing workloads?
  • How to ensure implementation best practices are followed?
  • How to reduce the deployment time?
  • How to technically validate the new infrastructure?
  • How to ensure proper governance to manage issues?

SAP has created a global framework for the build phase that spans the multi-cloud Infrastructure ecosystem.
This framework covers best practices for migration into the cloud, automated provisioning, deployment, and
validation of SAP systems. This allows our customers to safely adopt and run new SAP software innovations
because cloud services are tested and made production-ready before they are made available to customers.

  • Datacenter facilities, physical hardware and connectivity
  • Infrastructure Provisioning: Certified compute, storage, and network components are deployed using automated tools and DevOps methodologies.
  • Technical Managed Services required to build and deliver the infrastructure
  • Software Stack: SAP installs and configures OS, databases, and ERP applications, including industry best practices.
  • Operational Tooling: Licensing and integration of provisioning, monitoring, backup, and cybersecurity tools.

3. Operate Phase

The primary goal of the operate phase is to provide ongoing support, infrastructure management, change
management and the technical services necessary to run the application. There are several complex topics
that need to be addressed during this phase:

  • How should the SLAs be measured?
  • How to manage the changes?
  • How to automate and achieve operational efficiency?
  • How to manage security incidents and threats?
  • How to keep SAP applications up-to-date?
  • How to address capacity planning?

SAP Enterprise Cloud Services accelerates and simplifies customers’ business transformation by running their SAP systems with a world-class level of availability, security and resilience, supported by an application-level SLA and a managed cloud service tailored to SAP systems. After a successful transition from the build phase to the operate phase, the ongoing support work is performed, along with additional application deployment activities. It covers the management of the installed infrastructure and applications, scaling the infrastructure, and managing ITIL processes through an engagement model with proven governance to secure business continuity.

  • Datacenter & Capacity Management: Continuous infrastructure optimization, backup integrity, and disaster recovery planning.
  • Security Operations: 24/7 threat detection, patching, vulnerability scanning, and advanced forensics.
  • Service Management: ITIL-based workflows, global support teams, and dedicated technical service managers ensure SLA adherence and business continuity.

Selecting the right deployment for your ERP system

Through SAP's Technical Assessment process, we work closely with each customer to address all questions related to the design, build, and operation of SAP in Cloud ERP Private. During this assessment, SAP provides detailed insights into the cloud service elements and explains the available options for transitioning to SAP Cloud ERP Private.

One such option is SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper, which helps customers extend support for their existing S/4HANA systems, ensuring business continuity: Bridging the gap with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper

SAP ECS empowers enterprises to move legacy ERP systems to private cloud environments without compromising control, compliance, or customisation. Our private cloud strategy serves as a blueprint for scalable, secure, and intelligent ERP modernisation.

entry.title: Linux Shell Script for automating graceful startup and shutdown of SAP S4HANA System
entry.content:
Linux Shell Script for automating graceful startup and shutdown of SAP S4HANA [Only meant for Single Tier System] in SUSE Linux VMs/Instances inside cloud environment.

 

This post is purely focusing on the OS level scripting and is not associated with nor related with any of the cloud console level automation using serverless concepts, for example AWS Lambda.

 

Running SAP S4HANA on virtual machines in cloud environments like Azure, AWS, or Google Cloud comes with its unique challenges—especially when it comes to starting and stopping services reliably and cost-effectively.

 

As most of us are familiar, when a VM or Instance boots up, post the OS booting process, it’s critical to start the SAP HANA database *before* the SAP application to avoid issues/failures. Similarly, during a VM shutdown, the SAP application must stop *before* the database to ensure all processes close gracefully, preventing data corruption or downtime.

 

Leaving SAP systems running idle can also cause unnecessary cloud billing, especially in PoC or Demo setups where uptime directly impacts costs.

 

To address the above mentioned two of the key issues, I developed simple yet effective shell scripts that automate the controlled start and stop sequence of SAP S4HANA based on the VM’s lifecycle. These scripts can be manually invoked or integrated into cloud startup/shutdown hooks, ensuring SAP services respond correctly whenever the OS boots or halts.

 

This automation enhances reliability and saves effort and rework by enabling the graceful shutting down of SAP S4HANA App and DB.

 

Here’s how it works:

To achieve the above-mentioned automation, you need to follow the steps mentioned below

 

  1.       Logon with root user on the VM/instance where SAP DB & Application is hosted.
  2.       Gain the clean root environment with default variables and path using the command: sudo su -
  3.       Navigate to the path: /etc/systemd/system/
  4.       vi sap-s4hana.service
  5.       enter the following contents in this file.

Note: Please refer to the path used in this file content, you need to use same or in case you want to change the path or file naming convention etc., you may document the changes accordingly.

 

[Unit]

Description=SAP S/4HANA single-tier startup/shutdown orchestrator (HANA + App)

After=network.target

 

[Service]

Type=oneshot

ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/sap-start.sh

ExecStop=/usr/local/bin/sap-stop.sh

RemainAfterExit=yes

TimeoutStartSec=1800

TimeoutStopSec=1800

 

[Install]

WantedBy=multi-user.target

 

  1.       save the file
  2.       Update the permissions of this file: chmod +x sap-s4hana.service
  3.       Update file ownership of this file: chown root:root sap-s4hana.service
  4.       For creating the shell script for starting the SAP S4HANA DB and SAP S4 Application, Navigate to the path:

/usr/local/bin

vi sap-start.sh

  1. 10.  enter the following contents in this file:

Note: Please refer to the path used in this file content, you need to use same or in case you want to change the path or naming convention, you may document the changes accordingly.

Ensure to update the relevant user id, SAP SID, Instance Numbers in this content,

 

#!/bin/bash

LOGFILE="/var/log/sap-start.log"

exec >> "$LOGFILE" 2>&1

echo "===== [$(date)] Starting SAP S/4HANA DB ====="

# Start HANA DB

sudo -u xxxadm /usr/sap/XXX/HDB02/HDB start

echo "HANA DB start command executed."

# Wait for DB

sudo -u xxxadm /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 02 -function WaitforStarted 600

echo "HANA DB started successfully."

echo "===== [$(date)] Starting SAP Application ====="

# Start SAP App

sudo -u xxxadm /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 00 -function StartSystem

echo "SAP Application start command executed."

# Wait for SAP App

sudo -u xxxadm /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 00 -function WaitforStarted 300

echo "SAP Application started successfully."

echo "===== [$(date)] SAP System Startup Completed ====="

  1. 11.  save the file
  2. 12.  Update the permissions of this file: chmod 777 sap-start.sh
  3. 13.  Update the ownership of this file: chown root:root sap-start.sh

 

 

 

  1. 14.  For creating the shell script for stopping the SAP S4 Application & SAP S4HANA DB, continue in same folder, and follow the steps below:

/usr/local/bin

vi sap-stop.sh

  1.   #!/bin/bash
  2.   LOGFILE="/var/log/sap-stop.log”
  3. 17.  exec >> "$LOGFILE" 2>&1
  4. 18.  echo "===== [$(date)] Stopping SAP Application ====="
  5.   # Stop SAP App
  6. 20.  sudo -u xxxadm /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 00 -function StopSystem
  7. 21.  echo "SAP Application stop command executed."
  8.   # Wait for SAP App
  9. 23.  sudo -u xxxadm /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 00 -function WaitforStopped 300
  10.   echo "SAP Application stopped successfully."
  11. 25.  echo "===== [$(date)] Stopping HANA DB ====="
  12.   # Stop HANA DB
  13.   sudo -u xxxadm /usr/sap/XXX/HDB02/HDB stop
  14. 28.  echo "HANA DB stop command executed."
  15.   # Wait for DB
  16. 30.  sudo -u xxxadm /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 02 -function WaitforStopped 600
  17. 31.  echo "HANA DB stopped successfully."
  18. 32.  echo "===== [$(date)] SAP System Shutdown Completed ====="
  19. 33.  save the file
  20. 34.  Update the permissions of this file: chmod 777 sap-stop.sh
  21. 35.  Update the ownership of this file: chown root:root sap-stop.sh
  22.   During your copying of the above-mentioned commands and scripts in the linux host, quite often the files might get appended with carriage returns (^M , \r ), this can be concluded during checking of the above created files using the cat command, if fould, you can use one of the following command to clean for each of the three files created above :

sudo dos2unix filename                                [or]

sudo sed -I ‘s/\r$//’ filename

  1. 37.  Further to the completion of above steps, navigate to the path /etc/systemd/system

sudo systemctl daemon-reload

sudo systemctl enable sap-s4hana.service

  1. 38.  If you have not started the SAP S4HANA DB and S4 Application, you can proceed to execute

sudo systemctl start sap-s4hana.service

By executing this command, you must check the progress of DB status and Application status using the sapcontrol command

  1. 39.  Post checking the proper starting of the SAP S4HANA DB and S4 Application, you can also check the proper stopping by executing the following command

sudo systemctl stop sap-s4hana.service

By executing this command, you must check the progress of DB status and Application status using the sapcontrol command

  

Why This Matters

- Protects SAP data integrity with clean startups and shutdowns  

- Saves cloud costs, ideal for PoC / Demo / Dev environments  

- Makes manual intervention unnecessary, cutting operational overhead

entry.title: Sizing Your Success: A Guide to SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
From my perspective, effective sizing is one of the most underestimated yet critical aspects of any SAP transformation. While SAP offers a standardized and well-defined architecture, every customer’s landscape, data footprint, and performance expectations are unique. This makes it essential for customers and their implementation partners to take ownership of sizing, validation, and optimization activities.

For SAP customers, partners, and technical teams navigating the shift to SAP S/4HANA and other solutions within SAP Cloud ERP Private, accurate system sizing is paramount. While SAP provides a globally consistent, standardized architecture, the responsibility for executing and validating sizing activities rests squarely with the customer and their implementation partners.

Ultimately, accurate sizing isn’t just a technical exercise; it’s a strategic enabler for stability, scalability, and long-term cost efficiency.

This guide demystifies SAP sizing, focusing on the core concepts, benefits, and practical methods within the SAP Cloud ERP Private landscape.

What is SAP Cloud ERP Private?

SAP Cloud ERP Private is a cloud-based offering that marries the control of an on-premise system with the agility and efficiency of the cloud. It guides customers toward a clean core through standardized processes and modern extensibility via SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), and in-app extensibility tools.

I think the biggest advantage of running SAP on certified cloud infrastructure that SAP Cloud ERP Private oferring adheres to is how it simplifies everything — security, compliance, and support are all built in. It lets IT teams spend less time keeping the lights on and more time driving innovation. The key, though, is being ready to fully embrace the cloud mindset to get the most out of it.

For more information please refer to Understanding the Distinct Scope of SAP Cloud ERP Private.

General SAP Sizing Overview

SAP sizing is the process of precisely determining the required hardware resources such as CPU, memory, storage, and network capacity to effectively support an SAP system based on specific business needs. It’s a blend of science, utilizing tools and calculations, and expert judgment to account for the unique context of each implementation.

Key aspects of sizing include:

  • Translating Business Requirements: Starting with user counts, transaction volumes, data growth, and performance expectations.
  • Hardware Determination: Calculating the required compute, memory, and storage.
  • Iterative Process: Sizing isn't a one-time event. It must be revisited as the business and technology evolve. This is because sizing relies on assumptions and approximations about future usage, and it must balance optimal performance with cost management.
  • Data Quality is Critical: The accuracy of the sizing results is heavily dependent on the quality of the validated usage data and sizing assumptions provided by customers and partners.

SAP Cloud ERP Private Sizing Strategy

Sizing for SAP Cloud ERP Private is a vital step to ensure your infrastructure efficiently supports your SAP workloads. SAP offers two primary models:

  1. Standard Sizing: A simplified, consumption-based model using predefined T-shirt size service bundles (e.g., XXS to 4XL), which provides a baseline scope with a minimal sizing effort.
  2. Tailored Sizing: A more granular, customized approach for complex landscapes, offering greater flexibility based on detailed requirements.

Key Sizing Steps

A structured approach to sizing includes:

  • Define the Scope: Identify the SAP applications (e.g., SAP S/4HANA, SAP BW/4HANA) and specific modules, determine transaction workloads, and define usage (e.g., Production, QA).
  • Collect Baseline Data: Use tools like the SAP Quick Sizer for new systems or EarlyWatch Reports and historical data (ST03N / ST06) for existing ones. For migrations, the SAP Readiness Check is essential.
  • Use SAP Sizing Tools: Leverage tools like Quick Sizer (greenfield) or specific sizing reports like /SDF/HDB_SIZING (brownfield) to get technical resource estimates.
  • Incorporate Growth & Buffer: Always plan for projected growth (3–5 years) and add a buffer (typically 10–25%) for peak loads and future needs.
  • Validate with Experts: Review and validate sizing with SAP experts, potentially via a "Size to Scale" engagement through SAP Premium Engagement.

Standard Sizing: The T-Shirt Model

The Standard approach maps your business needs to a predefined, T-shirt-sized model.

Full User Equivalent (FUE)

The starting point for Standard sizing is calculating the Full User Equivalent (FUE). An FUE reflects the average workload of a typical user, with different user types weighted accordingly:

The final FUE count determines the required hardware package.

Tailored Sizing: Customization for Complexity

The Tailored Option provides granular control and customized hardware specifications. This model combines standard tools with deep expert analysis, allowing more precise control over application server sizing and high-availability (HA)/disaster-recovery (DR) configurations.

In a tailored environment, the strategy shifts to "right-sizing" for current needs. This means leveraging the cloud’s elasticity to scale up or down instead of provisioning for multi-year growth upfront, which is the case for traditional on-premise models.

Refer to the Key Resources section for tools and reports that will help you identify the right option for your scope.

“Size to Scale” and Technical Assessment

The SAP Cloud ERP Private Technical Assessment is a mandatory, comprehensive evaluation designed to analyze and document the technical requirements, architecture, and sizing needs.

SAP Expert Sizing Engagement

For complex, large, or unusual landscapes, engaging an SAP expert is highly recommended. The "Size to Scale" is the expert sizing service from SAP offered via SAP Premium Engagements (MaxAttention or ActiveAttention). It provides a deep-dive, tailored sizing service.

When is "Size to Scale" required?

SAP proactively escalates an implementation for expert review if:

  • Initial analysis indicates a SAP HANA DB Requirement > 4 TiB.
  • A large amount of custom code is being migrated.
  • There are plans to consolidate multiple ERP solutions or significant new functionality (e.g., embedded EWM/TM).

SAP Sizing & Technical Assessment Engagement Flow

The sizing process is a multi-step flow involving different teams:

  1. Initiation & Scoping: Define objectives and scope with Customer, SAP Account Executives, and SAP Cloud Architecture & Advisory (CAA).
  2. Data Collection & Pre-Assessment: Customer and partner run sizing reports (e.g., /SDF/HDB_SIZING, SAP Readiness Check) and collect historical performance data.
  3. Sizing Analysis: The SAP CAA team analyzes data, maps it to infrastructure (T-shirt or tailored specs), and applies the necessary growth buffer.
  4. Technical Assessment Review & Validation: Finalized sizing assumptions are reviewed, aligned on HA/DR/network, documented in the Technical Assessment Report, and signed off by the customer.
  5. Handover to Delivery: The infrastructure is provisioned as per the agreed specifications.

Monitoring and Reporting in Cloud ERP, Private

After provisioning, continuous monitoring is key to validating the sizing and ensuring performance. This is managed through core services provided as part of the SAP Cloud ERP Private offering:

  • Capacity Management: This ongoing process ensures the environment meets performance and availability requirements by monitoring utilization, forecasting demand, and dynamically adjusting resource allocation.
  • Problem Management: This function identifies, analyzes, and resolves capacity and performance issues. It links directly back to sizing by investigating if initial assumptions were inaccurate and recommending a necessary resizing or optimization.
  • Performance Benchmarking (Enhanced Operations Services for Large Enterprises – EOS LE): A jointly defined service that measures selected business transactions over time, helping to identify performance trends and proactively mitigate future issues. 

    For more information on EOS LE please refer to SAP Cloud ERP, Private Service Description site.

By diligently performing and validating your sizing assumptions, your organization can ensure that your SAP S/4HANA journey in SAP Cloud ERP Private is built on a foundation of optimal performance, scalability, and cost efficiency.

Greenfield vs. Brownfield: Sizing Strategies for SAP S/4HANA Success

When moving to SAP S/4HANA, especially within the SAP Cloud ERP Private environment, the path you choose dictates your sizing strategy. Do you start fresh (greenfield) or convert an existing system (brownfield)?

While both methods rely on core SAP sizing tools, the inputs, assumptions, and required infrastructure for CPU, RAM, and storage diverge significantly. Understanding these differences is crucial for accurate provisioning and avoiding costly over- or under-sizing.

Sizing Approaches: Greenfield vs. Brownfield at a Glance

Aspect

Greenfield Sizing

Brownfield Sizing

Data Volume

Sizing Buffer

Greenfield Sizing: Building from the Blueprint

Use Case: A new SAP S/4HANA system deployment, often involving redefined, standardized business processes and a selective data migration.

Key Considerations:

  • Reliance on SAP Quick Sizer: Since no historical data exists, sizing is purely business-driven. You input future metrics like the number of users by type, sales order volumes, and financial transaction counts. The Quick Sizer outputs estimates for SAP HANA memory, CPU cores, and disk sizes.
  • Reduced Data Footprint: Greenfield often means selective data migration (e.g., only the last 2–3 years of transactional history). This results in a smaller initial database, lower storage requirements, and reduced initial RAM needs.
  • Cleaner Architecture: With fewer customizations and a focus on standard SAP S/4HANA processes, sizing for application performance is more predictable.
  • Add a Growth Buffer: As with any new implementation, add a significant buffer (typically ~20–30%) to account for future data growth, unforeseen business process changes, or new functionality adoption.

Brownfield Sizing: Converting the Past to the Future

Use Case: Converting an existing SAP ECC or SAP S/4HANA system to the private cloud, retaining existing processes and full data history.

Key Considerations:

  • Historical Data Analysis is Key: Sizing is usage-based. You must analyze the current system's historical performance to get an accurate estimate.
    • Workload Analysis: Use ST03N (workload analysis) and ST06 (system resources) data, and EarlyWatch Reports to understand CPU and memory utilization patterns.
    • Data Archiving is Best Practice: To optimize your sizing, archive and clean up unnecessary data before running the sizing reports.
  • The Crucial Sizing Report: The primary tool is the SAP HANA Sizing Report (/SDF/HDB_SIZING), detailed in SAP Note 1872170. This report runs on your existing system to analyze current database size, compression factors, and transaction volumes, providing a precise estimate of the required SAP HANA memory.
  • Accounting for Custom Code: Custom programs and reports (often numerous in an SAP ECC system) require assessment. The Custom Code Analyzer helps evaluate their impact, as unoptimized custom code can significantly increase required CPU and RAM.
  • Include Conversion Load: Be aware that the migration itself requires a temporary sizing uplift for staging, code remediation, and data transformation activities.

Key Recommendations and Next Steps

Sizing is a collective responsibility. While SAP and its certified partners provide the tools and expertise, customers must provide validated data and usage assumptions.

Always Validate:

  • Consult Experts: Always validate your sizing results—especially for complex brownfield conversions—with SAP CAA or a "Size to Scale" expert engagement through SAP Premium Engagement.
  • Compare Results: If you are unsure, run both the Quick Sizer (for a clean slate estimate) and the sizing reports (for historical usage) and compare the outcomes.
  • Documentation is Key: All sizing assumptions, data sources, and final resource estimates must be formally documented in the Technical Assessment Report as part of your SAP Cloud ERP Private onboarding.
